item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds PC Patch Confirms DLC Check Glitch
item.content:encoded:
If you're a Monster Hunter Wilds PC player and you're sick of the game's poor performance on your rig, Capcom may have the answer to your prayers, and the studio has confirmed an enterprising player's theory about the source of some of the issues as well.

In a news post on Steam, Capcom says it's released a patch for Monster Hunter Wilds that includes "optimization improvements for Steam-specific processes and options to reduce processing load", so your machine should have an easier time running the game now.

Capcom points to a CPU load issue caused by "claimed content status check processes" intended to notify players if unclaimed content is waiting for them, which confirms the results of an experiment performed by a Monster Hunter Wilds player earlier this month.

According to Capcom, this problem should only cause Wilds' FPS to drop "in the Base Camp and Grand Hub", and how much DLC you own doesn't matter; if you have any unclaimed DLC at all, you may run into the issue.

More improvements and optimizations are planned for Monster Hunter Wilds, too; in February, another patch will arrive that aims to "reduce GPU processing load by adding quality levels (LOD) to the polygon mesh for 3D models".

In case you're wondering, LOD stands for "level of detail", and, as you can imagine, it refers to the amount of complexity in the detail of 3D models for characters and other assets.

Remarkably, Capcom says this solution would involve "swapping to low-resolution models for objects farther away from the camera", which implies that Monster Hunter Wilds doesn't already do this. That would probably go some way towards explaining some of the FPS issues experienced by PC players. Yikes.

Monster Hunter Wilds is available now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and its latest update can be downloaded right now on PC. Why not head in and see whether it's improved your performance? While you wait, be sure to check out our review of the game.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Scott Pilgrim EX Release Date Revealed for March, Two New Characters Unveiled
item.content:encoded:
Retro-style brawler Scott Pilgrim EX now has a release date, developer and publisher Tribute Games has announced, and the studio has also revealed two more fighters joining the side-scroller's roster.

According to a new official trailer, Scott Pilgrim EX will be arriving across PC and consoles on March 3rd, and what's more, two erstwhile foes, Matthew Patel and Robot-01, will be available to play as if you're looking for allies.

They'll join a roster that also includes playable characters from Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game, like Scott himself and Ramona Flowers, although iconic characters like Knives Chau and Wallace Weldon won't be playable in the game.

If you're not familiar with Scott Pilgrim EX, it's a brand new side-scrolling beat-'em-up from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge and Marvel Cosmic Invasion studio Tribute Games.

Although the name might suggest otherwise, Scott Pilgrim EX isn't an expanded re-release of Ubisoft's rather excellent 2010 side-scroller Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game; instead, it's a completely new title, and it boasts an all-new story penned by series creator Bryan Lee O'Malley.

Gameplay-wise, as you've probably come to expect from Tribute Games, you can expect chaotic pixel-based side-scrolling action, with screens full of enemies to defeat and retro art to enjoy, plus tons of classic video game references.

Not only that, but each playthrough allows you to collect and spend coins to upgrade your characters and equip special items, leading to the potential for "a unique build for every playthrough", as Tribute tells it.

You can check out the new release date trailer for Scott Pilgrim EX, which also shows off Matthew Patel and Robot-01, right here.

Scott Pilgrim EX is set to arrive on PC, PlayStation, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch on March 3rd. If you're in the mood for some time-traveling, why not check out our review of Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game - Complete Edition from back in 2021?

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Monster Train 2 Sales Reach 500k as First DLC Gears Up for February Launch
item.content:encoded:
Monster Train 2 is getting its first major DLC expansion next week, publisher Devolver Digital and developer Shiny Shoe have revealed, and the game has passed a major sales milestone as well.

Per a press release, Monster Train 2 sales have hit 500,000 since the game launched in May last year, which puts the deckbuilding card battler on par with fellow hits like No, I'm Not a Human and Inazuma Eleven: Victory Road.

Alongside celebrating the new sales milestone, Devolver and Shiny Shoe also revealed Destiny of the Railforged, the first major Monster Train 2 expansion. It's set to arrive on February 2nd (that's next Monday at time of writing).

The DLC will bring a new game mode to Monster Train 2, in which you'll be battling bosses in "any order you wish" and using the souls you gain from those bosses to boost the power of your deck.

Shiny Shoe and Devolver are promising "a challenge wholly unique from the base game" in the Soul Savior mode, as well as a new cosmic setting that lets you loose on both familiar faces and entirely new monsters.

A brand new clan, the Railforged, will also be joining the fray, with two new playable characters representing said clan: Herzal, the blacksmith who made your train, and Heph, who built the game's Skullcrusher engine.

Even if you're not planning to pick up Monster Train 2's Destiny of the Railforged DLC, you can look forward to a free update that reintroduces the Wurmkin clan from the original Monster Train. All players can enjoy that update without paying a penny.

If you're wondering exactly what Monster Train 2 is, it's the followup to the original Monster Train, and like its predecessor, it's a roguelike deckbuilder in which you'll be doing battle with a variety of infernal foes through card-based combat.

You can check out Monster Train 2 right now on PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch, and you can check out our review here.
